awd_titl_txt: Scholarships for Service: Increasing Talented Trus
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Houston (UH) seeks to establish a CyberCorps(R): Scholarship for Service (SFS) program to prepare graduate students for government service in order to help secure, protect and defend our Nation's information systems.  UH proposes to support 3 PhD students and 9 MS students.   UH is classified as a Very High Research University, is classified as a Hispanic-Serving institution, and has been designated as a Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education since 2009.  This project seeks to address the needs of the Gulf-coast region and beyond, the need of the nation for cybersecurity professionals, and the need for more women and underrepresented minorities in cybersecurity.

The focus of the project is on enriching cybersecurity education with related fields such as data mining, machine learning, statistics and natural language processing.   UH proposes to build a community of well-qualified scholars in trusted computing, provide a rich set of theoretical and applied cybersecurity experiences for the students, foster diversity in the student pool, and disseminate successful models of cybersecurity education to the nation.   The education plan includes the use of cyberwar and laboratory exercises for community building and peer mentoring.  Professional development activities planned include workshops focused on professional skill development, seminars, and external visits to government agencies and research institutes.

por.por_cntn:
In our proposal, we had proposed to support nine MS students and three PhD students. As of the end of the project (July 2023), we have recruited 14 MS students and three PhD students, exceeding our goals by 42%. Our MS students include four women (29% of MS students versus 26% for all SFS programs over 2015-2021 as per the GAO report  on Diversity), three African Americans students including two women (17% of all SFS students, versus  11% for SFS programs over 2015-2021 as per the GAO report  on Diversity). We have graduated 12 MS students successfully so far, two MS students left the program after one year, and we expect to graduate one PhD student in 2024. Eleven MS students have been placed in qualifying positions and four have already completed their service terms. 

New Course & Curricular Innovations: The SFS grant led to the creation and teaching of a new Security Analytics course, which is now a regular course at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. PI Verma has also been pivotal in creating a security capstone at the undergraduate level. The PI also helped with the Cybersecurity inventory led by another SFS institution.

Our SFS project led to two new regular courses at UG and graduate levels: security analytics, combining data science and cybersecurity. SFS students have authored eight MS theses on security topics and co-authored 16 peer-reviewed publications on security, and related, topics and one patent. The grant has partly supported SFS project team members on one book (Cybersecurity Analytics, CRC Press 2019), 27 additional (co-authored by SFS faculty) peer-reviewed research publications on security topics such as malware clustering, intrusion detection, phishing detection, domain-independent deception, cloud security, and blockchains, etc., in leading venues several conference/workshop proceedings  and a patent.

In addition to the societal benefits of the SFS graduates' cybersecurity work, four SFS students participated in the INSuRE project (in which external scientists from FFRDCs co-mentored them) and gave presentations to professionals from universities and FFRDCs. An Ethical Hackers Club was started for applied experiences in cybersecurity, which is open to all interested students at UH. The SFS scholars and project team gave many presentations, tutorials and keynotes at workshops, conferences, universities (e.g., Syracuse U., New Mexico Tech., U. of Monterrey, etc.), and research laboratories  (e.g., Samsung and Amazon Research). The PI also used social media posts to “educate” the broader public on cybersecurity threats. The inspiration for pursuing a STEM education and Cybersecurity career of some SFS students was studied and reported in four peer-reviewed publications and a book, one of the papers received an American Educational Research Association Outstanding Award.

Faculty Development: We have been co-organizing the Association for Computing Machinery Annual International Workshop on Security and Privacy Analytics (IWSPA) since 2015, and the International Workshop for Hardware Security and Privacy (HASP) since 2012. In particular, IWSPA intertwines research with education, with dedicated tutorials for faculty development. Five workshops were organized at UH specifically for faculty development. Collectively, these workshops attracted about 500 faculty and PhD students.

Integration of Research & Education: The Security Analytics course includes recent research progress on a variety of cybersecurity topics, including malware, social engineering attacks, and intrusion detection. The IWSPA workshops also include both research and education sessions.

Mentoring Non-SFS Institutions: As part of UH's Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) for security education and research designations, we participate in the Southwest Regional Hub, consisting of CAE universities from Hawaii to Louisiana. The network allows us an excellent opportunity to reach out to non-SFS institutions ranging from community colleges to tier-one research universities. We have advertised the SFS program and mentored some Hub faculty members, e.g., from Texas A&M-San Antonio University and Univ. of Texas-Rio Grande Valley.

Assessment Outcomes: Participating SFS students unanimously praised the team’s strengths in teaching, mentoring, and seeking jobs/internships. All but two students completed the program, with one experiencing difficulties with a prerequisite course during Covid, and another demonstrated deep hacking skills on an assignment contrary to course policy. Over 80% of the SFS students work/worked for govt. agencies with two to three still searching. Several SFS students complained about the ineffectiveness of the virtual career fairs held during Covid in lieu of the in-person annual career fairs.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2024
Modified by: Rakesh M Verma
